channel.title: My First Python Game
channel.description:
I recently (last week) began to look at Python since Java and the others tended to go over my head. I figured, let's try Python to learn some things and then move onto another language. So I started working on a text game (CMD based) and realized it sucked. So I started again, keeping my code organized and slightly neater and started adding some different elements. Right now, it is pretty bare, but I am learning how to incorporate more as I go.
[u]The Game[/u] The game is a basic, nine room exploration to find the objects needed to escape. As of now, it only handles the rooms and object finding, but I have an idea of what I am going to add as I go.
The code is to many characters to be pasted here, so I will leave the link to the GitHub for the project. https://github.com/Pythonier/Rooms-of-Mystery
If I have to have some of the project within the thread, please let me know, and I will grab some of the code for here.
Please, don't flame me or anything since I am new. I am open to all constructive criticism though!

item.title: My First Python Game
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

Looks pretty good; it reminds me of my own Python game, but I think yours is better. https://github.com/Whackatre/Python_Projects/blob/master/JunkFactory.py

Read full topic

item.title: My First Python Game
item.dc:creator: @Morx Morx
item.description:
@Morx wrote:

Gosh close to 1K lines of code for this, Well i hope you keep working on it and make some recent updates.

Read full topic

item.title: My First Python Game
item.dc:creator: @iCreatedHorror Ryan
item.description:
@iCreatedHorror wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:2, topic:449169”]I would recommend using a Room object rather than defining a method for each room, this way you’ll be able to generalise chunks of code and keep it cleaner overall.[/quote]I thought about it, but since I like to try and teach myself as much as I can, I wasn’t sure how to get what I wanted.

How would I create the Room object and still allow each room to have it’s “unique” features such as the objects it contains for that room alone? A link to a tutorial or of the which helps me would also be extremely helpful (I’ve read LPTHW and the tutorials on the Python site, but I may have missed something).

Edit: I am open to all criticism and/or help anyone is willing to give. I am not open to things such as “add this or this” or “this sucks” as they don’t help me learn and get better in any way. Thank you.

Read full topic

item.title: My First Python Game
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

I would recommend using a Room object rather than defining a method for each room, this way you’ll be able to generalise chunks of code and keep it cleaner overall.

Read full topic

item.title: My First Python Game
item.dc:creator: @iCreatedHorror Ryan
item.description:
@iCreatedHorror wrote:

I recently (last week) began to look at Python since Java and the others tended to go over my head. I figured, let’s try Python to learn some things and then move onto another language. So I started working on a text game (CMD based) and realized it sucked. So I started again, keeping my code organized and slightly neater and started adding some different elements. Right now, it is pretty bare, but I am learning how to incorporate more as I go.

The Game
The game is a basic, nine room exploration to find the objects needed to escape. As of now, it only handles the rooms and object finding, but I have an idea of what I am going to add as I go.

The code is to many characters to be pasted here, so I will leave the link to the GitHub for the project.

GitHub

Pythonier/Rooms-of-Mystery

Rooms-of-Mystery - Python console (CMD) game consisting of monsters, fighting, object finding, escape. Concept One (V1) in progress.

If I have to have some of the project within the thread, please let me know, and I will grab some of the code for here.

Please, don’t flame me or anything since I am new. I am open to all constructive criticism though!
